Running time: 57 minutes (71 minutes in 1998 George Eastman House restoration)
Article text: Straight Shooting   is a 1917 American  silent   Western  film directed by  John Ford  and featuring  Harry Carey   Prints of this film survive in the International Museum of Photography and Film at  George Eastman House     1    Like many American films of the time   Straight Shooting  was subject to cuts by  city and state film censorship boards   The Chicago Board of Censors refused to issue a permit for this film as submitted as it consists of detailed portrayal of murder and outlawry    2       At the end of the 19th century in the Far West  a farmer is fighting for his right to plough the plains  In order to expel the farmers  the ranchers try to control access to water    3
